subject: RE: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern + a suggestion for improving the Cookbook
msgSnippet: Eugene, Thank you for the example. Your example will work, but it seems more indirect to me (requiring more understanding of the framework) than overriding the
messageBody:
Eugene,

Thank you for the example. Your example will work, but it seems more
indirect to me (requiring more understanding of the framework) than
overriding the runTest() hook method.

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Eugene Kuleshov
> Sent: Wednesday, November 23, 2005 9:57 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern + a
> suggestion for improving the Cookbook
>
> Kent,
>
> How owerriding runtest() better then overriding getName() method?
> I usually use something like this (probably already posted
> this to the
> list about 4 times):
>
> public class MyTest extends TestCase {
> int param;
>
> public MyTest(int param) {
> super("testParam");
> this.param = param;
> }
>
> public void testParam() {
> ... assert
> }
>
> public String getName() {
> return super.getName()+" "+param;
> }
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite s = new TestSuite("MyTest");
> s.addTest(new MyTest(10));
> s.addTest(new MyTest(11));
> s.addTest(new MyTest(12));
> return s;
> }
>
> }
>
> regards,
> Eugene
>
>
> Kent Beck wrote:
>
> >Eugene,
> >
> >I recently wrote a tester that dynamically created tests and
> I was very glad
> >I knew to override runTest(). That way I could store useful
> information in
> >the name and have the tests print meaningfully in the test
> runner. I think
> >using the name as a pluggable selector is a little ugly, but
> justified given
> >how much it simplifies test writing.
> >
> >Kent Beck
> >Three Rivers Institute
> >
> >
> >
> >>-----Original Message-----
> >>From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> >>Behalf Of Eugene Kuleshov
> >>Sent: Monday, November 21, 2005 8:32 AM
> >>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> >>Subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern + a
> >>suggestion for improving the Cookbook
> >>
> >> I do believe that overriding runTest() is a really ugly
> hack. It is
> >>really enough to override getName() method to make suite tests look
> >>different.
> >>
> >>
>
>
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
